readability_reflection: In the survey, string interpolation was more readable than the other. Concatenation was more readable in code like "C://" + home, where there were a lot of symbols mixed in compared to interpolation with "C://{home}", but interpolation was more readable in "a = {a}" and "{name}, you scored {score} out of {total}" than concatenation.
comprehension_debugging: I have never seen string interpolation before this survey. With concatenation, it can be difficult to read sometimes when there's a lot concatenated.
preference_rationale: I'm inclined to stick with concatenation simply because I'm familiar with it, but if I get more experience with interpolation, I may opt for that in the cases it'd be more readable than concatenation.
learning_curve: It was difficult to determine how string interpolation worked since I've never seen it before. I only have experience with C++, but my understanding of concatenation was contradicting with the code examples in the survey. There were some like  "name = " + name + (1 + 2 + 3)  yet the answer choices would be like "name = name(123)" when I thought it'd be invalid.
